low.question: In everyday mathematics, what does the term 'percent' literally mean in English usage?
In printed documents and calculators, which character typically denotes percentage values?
Which basic statistical measure gives the arithmetic average value of a dataset?
When ordering data, which measure identifies the middle value splitting the dataset into halves?
Which basic statistic identifies the value that occurs most frequently in a dataset?
Which type of chart commonly displays proportional parts of a whole as slices?
Which common chart displays category comparisons using adjacent bars for each group?
Which graphical display shows the frequency distribution of continuous numerical data using bins?
Which basic measure describes the difference between the maximum and minimum values in a dataset?
In percentiles, which percentile rank denotes the dataset's middle value, also called the median?
What is the full range of probabilities expressed as percentages, from impossible event to certain event?
In statistics, what term describes a subset of individuals drawn from a larger population for study?
What term describes the complete set of individuals or items under study in a statistical investigation?
Which plot best visualizes the relationship between two quantitative variables as plotted points?
Which measure of central tendency remains more robust in the presence of extreme outliers?
For strongly skewed data, which central value typically represents the dataset better than the mean?
When summarizing categorical data, which measure identifies the most common category observed in the sample?
What term describes expressing a part of a whole by units out of one hundred?
What name is given to the three points that divide ordered data into four equal parts called quartiles?
Which percentage corresponds to an event that is certain to occur in probability terms?
Which symbol denotes per thousand, used occasionally in demographic and financial statistics?
Which statistical test is commonly used to check whether observed category counts match expected frequencies?
Which simple visual summarizes a five-number summary: minimum, first quartile, median, third quartile, maximum?
What single-word term describes a systematic deviation or consistent error introduced in measurement or sampling?
Which general term denotes how widely values in a dataset are spread or dispersed around a central value?
Which basic data operation arranges numerical observations from the smallest to the largest value in order?
Which statistic commonly denotes strength of evidence against a null hypothesis in many hypothesis tests?
What phrase describes a relative comparison of change measured against an original amount expressed in percent?
Which chart type combines bars with a cumulative percentage line and helps prioritize quality issues in work?
Which central measure is computed by summing all observed values and dividing by the total count of observations?

medium.question: Which nurse and statistician popularized the polar area 'coxcomb' chart to display causes of mortality visually?
Which Victorian-era scientist introduced early ideas about regression toward the mean and anthropometric studies?
Which statistician formalized the Pearson correlation coefficient for measuring linear association between variables?
Which statistician authored the influential book 'The Design of Experiments' and formalized analysis of variance methods?
Under what pen name did William Sealy Gosset publish his influential small-sample t-test research for quality control?
What rule approximates normal distribution coverage near one, two, and three standard deviations from the mean?
Which fundamental theorem explains why sample means approximate a normal distribution as sample size grows large?
Which measure represents the average squared deviation of observations from their arithmetic mean in a dataset?
Which sampling technique gives every individual in the population an equal probability of being selected for a survey?
Which numerical summary reflects both strength and direction of a linear relationship between two continuous variables?
What phrase describes an estimated interval that likely contains the true population parameter at a stated confidence level?
Which type I error describes rejecting a true null hypothesis and concluding an effect that does not exist?
Which error in hypothesis testing occurs when a false null hypothesis is not rejected, missing a real effect?
Which parametric test compares the means of two independent groups assuming approximate normality and similar variances?
Which nonparametric test compares paired observations when the assumption of normality is not satisfied?
Which computational technique estimates sampling variability by repeatedly resampling observed data with replacement?
Which statistic indicates the proportion of variance in a dependent variable that a model explains overall?
Which plot assesses whether sample quantiles align with a theoretical distribution, often used for normality checks?
Which average weights individual values by specified importance before summing and dividing by the total weights?
Which average multiplies values together and takes the nth root, useful for growth rates and ratios?
Which mean is most appropriate for averaging rates such as speeds when equal-distance segments are considered?
Which statistic is used to compare observed categorical frequencies to those expected under a null model?
What model evaluation technique repeatedly splits data into training and validation sets to estimate predictive performance?
Which rank-based correlation coefficient measures the strength of a monotonic relationship between two variables?
Which conventional significance threshold did Ronald Fisher propose as a practical cutoff for many tests?
Which curve plots cumulative share of a variable such as income against cumulative population proportion for inequality analysis?
Which index, computed from the Lorenz curve, quantifies inequality on a scale from zero to one typically?
Which reliability statistic assesses internal consistency of test or survey items based on average inter-item correlations?
Which common data transformation applies a logarithm to right-skewed positive data to stabilize variance?
Which regression technique models the probability of a binary outcome using the logit link and estimated coefficients?

hard.question: Who introduced the boxplot in exploratory data analysis to summarize distribution shape and identify outliers visually?
Which resampling technique estimates bias and variance by systematically leaving out one observation at a time?
Which statistician working at a brewery published the small-sample t-distribution under the pseudonym 'Student'?
Which widely cited multiple-testing procedure aims to control the expected proportion of false discoveries?
Which inequality gives an upper bound on the probability that a nonnegative random variable exceeds a positive threshold using its mean?
Which inequality provides a bound on the probability that any random variable deviates from its mean by a specified amount using variance?
Which statistical paradox demonstrates that aggregated data can display trends opposite to those in disaggregated subgroups?
Which normality test computes a statistic from ordered sample values and compares correlation with expected normal scores?
Which discrete probability distribution commonly models counts of rare independent events occurring in a fixed interval?
Which estimation principle finds parameter values that maximize the likelihood of the observed sample data under a model?
Which statistical test compares two nested models by taking the ratio of their maximized likelihoods?
Which regression framework models clustered or hierarchical data by including both fixed and random effects terms?
Which information criterion balances model fit against complexity by adding a penalty proportional to number of parameters?
Which class of algorithms generates samples from complex posterior distributions via random chains and transition kernels?
Which nonparametric test compares survival distributions between groups using observed-versus-expected event counts over time?
Which regularization method uses an L1 penalty to encourage sparse coefficient estimates in high-dimensional regression problems?
Which method reduces dimensionality by projecting original variables onto orthogonal directions that maximize variance explained?
Which diagnostic measure identifies observations that exert large influence on regression estimates if removed from the dataset?
Which test assesses the equality of variances across groups and is commonly used prior to comparing group means?
Which nonparametric estimator constructs the survival function from observed event times while accounting for censored observations?
Which general term describes a model's ability to maintain performance on unseen new data rather than just the training dataset?
Which form of bias occurs when participants choose to join a study, producing nonrepresentative samples due to voluntary response?
Which model selection criterion imposes a larger penalty for parameter count than AIC and often favors simpler models with large samples?
Which variance-stabilizing transformation commonly applies the square root to count data such as Poisson-distributed observations?
Which ensemble technique builds successive models to predict residuals and typically achieves strong performance in supervised learning tasks?
Which matrix summarizes variances on the diagonal and covariances off-diagonal for a set of multivariate observations?
Which nonparametric rank test compares two independent samples and is an alternative to the two-sample t-test under nonnormality?
Which concept defines a statistic that captures all the information in a sample relevant to estimating a parameter?
Which estimator property ensures estimates converge in probability to the true parameter value as sample size increases?
Which measure equals an estimator's variance plus the square of its bias, commonly used to assess estimator accuracy?
